properties.name: Dorich House Museum
properties.description: The former studio home of the sculptor Dora Gordine and her husband the Hon. Richard Hare, a scholar of Russian art and literature. 1930s house over four floors including a flat roof terrace and views of Richmond Park.

properties.name: The Old Finsbury Town Hall
properties.description: Opened by Lord Rosebery, an ornate building with elegant decor influenced by the Art Nouveau movement. Several notable rooms including the Great Hall with unique stained glass, antique mirrors and Clerkenwell Angel statuettes.

properties.name: 8 Stoneleigh Terrace (Highgate New Town, Stage 1)
properties.description: Built during the golden era of Camden public housing under Borough Architect Sydney Cook. Peter Tábori  studied with Ernő Goldfinger and worked with Denys Lasdun, and met Ken Adie when both were students at the Regent Street Polytechnic.

properties.name: Institut français du Royaume-Uni
properties.description: 1939 Art Deco Grade II listed building refurbished in 1950, then restructured and modernised in 2014. Contains an authentically classic cinema, private salons and multimedia library.

properties.name: Kingston Library, Museum and Art Gallery
properties.description: Adjoining Grade II listed Carnegie-funded library, museum and art gallery. Museum holdings range from ceramics to topographical drawings, including the collection left by Eadweard Muybridge, a native of Kingston and photographic pioneer.

properties.name: Kenwood
properties.description: A striking Neoclassical villa in tranquil gardens on Hampstead Heath, Kenwood boasts breath-taking interiors by Robert Adam and a world-class art collection. For guaranteed entry, book your free ticket via the English Heritage website.

properties.name: London Museum of Water & Steam
properties.description: The Museum is housed within in a unique collection of Grade I and II listed buildings. Even though they were purpose-built and purely functional buildings, the architect took great care to make the buildings aesthetically pleasing.

properties.name: Museum of London Docklands
properties.description: Grade I listed, late Georgian sugar warehouse now housing the Museum of London Docklands. Sensitively restored, the new multimedia displays coexist with the massive timber and brick structures of the original building.

properties.name: One Canada Square, Canary Wharf Group (CWG) Marketing Suite and Level39
properties.description: One of the most iconic structures dominating London’s skyline, One Canada Square is the third tallest building in the UK. It is Canary Wharf Group's landmark tower which houses Europe’s most influential FinTech scaler, Level39.

properties.name: Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery
properties.description: Designed by Sir John Soane as a family home and country residence. Following a three-year conservation project,  Pitzhanger has been returned to Soane’s innovative original design and re-opened to the public in March 2019.

properties.name: Pope's Grotto
properties.description: Grotto with mineral decoration is last remaining part of Alexander Pope's villa built 1720. The villa was demolished 1808 and replaced and redeveloped many times in following years but Pope's Grotto remains.

properties.name: Guildhall Art Gallery
properties.description: Houses the City of London's art collection, built over remains of London's 2C Roman amphitheatre. Façade uses Portland stone and Collyweston stone slates. Interior uses finishes of marble, American elm, damask and painted wall coverings.

properties.name: Rio Cinema
properties.description:
Grade II listed Art Deco cinema with stalls and circle created in 1937 within the shell of an Edwardian cinema, retaining many original features.
2017 new auditorium created in basement space.

properties.name: Royal Small Arms Factory
properties.description: Grade II listed arms factory closed to public for 170 years. Museum and clocktower open for tours.

properties.name: BedZED
properties.description: UK's first large-scale, mixed use eco-village and sustainable community. Completed in 2002, BedZED is an inspiration for low carbon neighbourhoods promoting One Planet Living. Developed in partnership with Peabody, ZEDfactory, Bioregional.

properties.name: St Paul's Cathedral - Triforium Tour
properties.description: Guided tours of the Triforium space to see: items from the cathedral collections including Christopher Wren’s magnificent ‘Great Model’ made in 1673; the Geometrical Staircase and the stunning view from the West Gallery.

properties.name: The City Churches: St Stephen Walbrook
properties.description: Wren's own and 'finest City Church'.  Fantastic architecture with different shapes,  twelve Corinthian columns and covered by huge dome - first of its type. Central stone altar by Henry Moore installed in 1987. Birthplace of the Samaritans.

properties.name: Brixton Windmill
properties.description: One of very few windmills in London. Built 1816 when Brixton Hill was open fields and a working mill until 1934. Restored to working order 2011.

properties.name: Argentine Ambassador's Residence
properties.description: Known as the 'Independent North Mansion' and christened by Sydney Herbert as 'Belgrave Villa' and then simply 'The Villa' by his successor the 6th Duke of Richmond. Owned by Argentina since 1936 and with sumptuous interiors still intact.

properties.name: The Ismaili Centre
properties.description: Part of an international family of Ismaili Centres, a religious, cultural and social space for the Shia Ismaili Muslim community. The serenity of the entrance fountain to the roof garden reflects Muslim traditions in architecture and design

properties.name: The Royal Society
properties.description: A spectacular Grade I listed building designed by famed architect John Nash. Built in 1831, these former townhouses have undergone refurbishments throughout their history. The building is now home to the UK's national science academy.

properties.name: Swiss Cottage Library
properties.description: Grade II listed building by renowned Modernist which has been refurbished and remodelled whilst protecting the building's landmark status.

properties.name: Vestry House Museum
properties.description: Meeting originally in the parish church, local ratepayers – the Vestry decided to build a workhouse for Walthamstow's poor in 1730. Later it was a police station then a private house, until in 1930 it became a museum of local history.

properties.name: The Church of Our Most Holy Redeemer
properties.description: A unique II* listed Italianate church by John Dando Sedding with attached Campanile and Institute Building. Of particular significance in the church is the imposing baldacchino over the High Altar, which dominates the east end.

properties.name: William Morris Gallery
properties.description: The William Morris Gallery is a fine example of Georgian domestic architecture dating from about 1744 (the date scratched on a brick). The house is Grade II* listed, and once the childhood home of the Arts & Crafts designer William Morris.

properties.name: Church of the Annunciation
properties.description: Fine Victorian church with large mosaic and painted reredos, screen and wall paintings and some unusual glass. Arts and crafts decoration by Nathaniel Westlake and Salviati Bros.

properties.name: St Dunstan and All Saints Church
properties.description: Grade I listed early medieval parish church (from 952 before Tower of London) in spacious churchyard. Fine interior: Anglo-Saxon Rood, Norman font, 'squint', fine memorials incl founders of Trinity House, 1950s glass. Bells of Stepney.

properties.name: St Jude on the Hill
properties.description: Eccentric Edwardian church, Grade I listed. Described by Simon Jenkins as 'one of Lutyens' most distinctive creations'. Extensive 20C wall-paintings by Walter Starmer, memorial to horses of WWI. Local archives display.

properties.name: St Paul's, Newington
properties.description: Modern architecture church with large copper and lead roof and concrete, brick and stained glass external structure. Marble, wood and plaster interior and artwork by Sculptor Freda Pinto and Gerald Holtom.

properties.name: Self-guided Architecture of Chislehurst Walk
properties.description: A look at some of the large houses built in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century by Ernest Newton, E. J May, Sir Aston Webb, Quennell and other noted architects.  Download from www.chislehurst-society.org.uk/CATTWALK.pdf

properties.name: The Old Palace, Bromley Civic Centre
properties.description: Old Palace was the official residence of the Bishops of Rochester. Present building dates from 1775, although there have been manor houses on the site since 10C.

properties.name: Canada House
properties.description: Canada's diplomatic home in the United Kingdom, the revitalised Canada House serves as a showcase for the very best of Canadian art and design in the 21C.

properties.name: The Old Bailey (Central Criminal Court)
properties.description: The Edwardian baroque of Mountford’s building has a base of Cornish granite with Portland stone facing above. Inside the lower grand hall and Grand Hall are lined with rich marble and the arches are of white Ancaster stone.

properties.name: Chiswick House
properties.description: One of the earliest and finest examples of Neo-Palladian design in the UK, Chiswick House is an 18C villa in west London. The 65 acres of Grade I listed gardens are the birthplace of the English Landscape Movement.

properties.name: Acland Burghley School
properties.description: An important example of 1960s comprehensive school design in the Brutalist style. Acland Burghley has recently celebrated its 50th anniversary and a Grade II listing.

properties.name: Colet House
properties.description: Unique building for artists with three large studios, all with north light through expansive windows. Originally called Barons Court Studio, Colet House was built 1885 on market garden land in what was a leafy backwater called Red Cow Lane.

properties.name: Cranford Stable Block & St Dunstan's Church
properties.description: 18th century stables of former Cranford House, seat of the Earls of Berkeley. Ha-ha and enclosed courtyard (the Secret Garden). St. Dunstan's Church with 17th century funeral monuments; 20th century work by Martin Travers.

properties.name: St Peter-in-the-Forest Church & Community Centre
properties.description: An 'Italian Romanesque' church set in Epping Forest, St Peter's was founded in 1840 and extended in 1887. The building underwent a major reordering throughout 2020 to save it from subsidence and create new community facilities.

properties.name: St Lawrence Church, Morden
properties.description: Grade I listed Norman brick-built church consisting of a nave and chancel. Tower at the west end. Gothic-style stone windows from the old church inserted into the present 1636 structure. East window stone likely to be from Merton Priory.

properties.name: St John the Divine
properties.description: St John’s has a wide nave approached via a narthex formed under the gallery running the width of the west end.  East of the nave is a chancel flanked to the south by the Lady Chapel and to the north by the organ chamber with loft over.

properties.name: Regent High School
properties.description: Five-time award-winning new build and refurbishment. The new building features a triple-storey 'arcade' that links to the existing Victorian building, simplifies movement around the school and provides passive supervision.

properties.name: Leathersellers' Hall
properties.description: New Livery Hall behind a retained early 20C façade. This is the 7th Hall in the Leathersellers' Company's history since its foundation in the Middle Ages.

properties.name: Whitehall Historic House
properties.description: Originally a farmer's house dating to 1500, with jettied upper storey. Later additions reflect the changing lifestyles of the owners, including the Killicks for over two centuries. Now houses scale model of Henry VIII's Nonsuch Palace.

properties.name: St George's German Lutheran Church
properties.description: The oldest surviving German church in England from 1763 with unaltered Georgian interior including box pews, German memorials and wheezy German Walcker organ from 1870.

properties.name: Honeywood Museum
properties.description: Chalk and flint house dating to 17C with additions including extensions of 1896 and 1903 when owned by John Pattinson Kirk. Rich in period detail and the interior restored and stairs opened up with funding from the Heritage Lottery Fund.

properties.name: City Information Centre
properties.description: London's main tourist information centre is clad in a specially manufactured system of 220 pre-finished stainless steel panels. This subtly reflective surface provides a striking counterpoint to St Paul's. RIBA Award Winner 2009.

properties.name: Blackheath Quaker Meeting House
properties.description: Small 1970s concrete building with a raised lantern. Designed to fit in with older buildings in the conservation area , and make the most of the split-level site. Architect Trevor Dannatt. Grade ll Listed.

properties.name: Pushkin House
properties.description: A centre of Russian culture in London, this Grade II* listed Georgian townhouse has a fine staircase which has been meticulously restored, and a large reception room for music salons.

properties.name: Uxbridge Quaker Meeting House
properties.description: An early 19C meeting house, with a little-altered large meeting room, within a garden – retains much of its original character and fabric, full-height shutters and fixed seating in the elders’ stand. Site of Quaker worship from late 1600s.

properties.name: A Ruskinian Walk Through Shared Heritage
properties.description: Ruskinian walk from RIBA award-winning Chiswick Business Park, Gunnersbury Triangle Nature Reserve through South Acton Estate, birthplace of artist Patrick Caulfield; Woodlands Park Ice House; to home of Wm Willett, of Daylight Saving Time

properties.name: Morley College Waterloo
properties.description: The Waterloo Centre, damaged in WWII and rebuilt in 1958 by Cowles Voysey and Brandon-Jones.

properties.name: Meridian Water Masterplan Tour
properties.description: A unique site in the borough of Enfield. Meridian Water will be a distinctive neighbourhood designed to nurture economic, environmental and social sustainability. The tour provides an insight to the soon to be bold and unique development.

properties.name: Romanian Cultural Institute
properties.description: Situated in one of the largest and grandest 19th century squares in London, 1 Belgrave Square was acquired by Romania in 1936 and is now home to the Romanian Cultural Institute.

properties.name: Roca London Gallery
properties.description: A unique space where water acts as the architectural theme - offering an innovative and interactive experience with Roca, the global bathroom brand.

properties.name: Embassy of the Republic of Estonia
properties.description: Representing Neo-Classicist style characteristic of the mid-19C, many of the details of the house have been restored to their original splendour. The interior design is inspired by Estonian nature: swamps, lakes and forests.

properties.name: Darbishire Place (Peabody Whitechapel Estate)
properties.description: New block of 13 homes which completes an ensemble of six housing blocks surrounding an internal courtyard.The façade complements the existing Victorian buildings by Henry Astley Darbishire. RIBA Award Winner & Stirling Prize shortlist 2015

properties.name: St Mary Magdalene
properties.description: A historic living parish church, progressively shaped from the Tudor to the Edwardian period. St Mary's has recently undergone a major refurbishment and the newly restored windows recapture the original airiness of the C18 nave.

properties.name: The Wheelhouse
properties.description: Listed building with unique 7-spoke Victorian waterwheel, the only daily working example in South London, originally used by Liberty's for rinsing printed silk, and now the home of a craft pottery and art studio.

properties.name: Barking Town Centre Tour
properties.description: Barking town centre has seen significant development over recent years with substantial growth in housing and infrastructure. These guided tours will visit existing award winning schemes and set out the vision for the future of the town.

properties.name: Cressingham Gardens
properties.description: Low-rise high density estate located next to Brockwell Park. Innovative design with pioneering architectural elements & echoing natural topography. Under threat of demolition by Lambeth council. Tours provided of estate and rotunda.

properties.name: German Historical Institute
properties.description: This Grade II* listed building includes an Adam-style ceiling on the 1st floor and a beautiful staircase with wrought-iron balustrade. Once home to the Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain, it now houses an historical research institute.

properties.name: St Mary of Eton Church Mixed Use Development
properties.description: Spacious Refurbished Grade II* listed church with new community facilities, new housing. 2015 RIBA Award, New London Architecture Award, Housing Design Award.

properties.name: The Library at Willesden Green
properties.description: A modern 4-storey building incorporating the much-loved Victorian library. The galleries and feature walls display exhibitions and contemporary art and a dramatic central atrium provides natural ventilation and daylight throughout.

properties.name: Tin House
properties.description: Making efficient use of an irregular urban site, this house is made up of interconnecting top-lit pavilions arranged to define a tranquil private courtyard.

properties.name: Anise Gallery / AVR London
properties.description: An 1870s Zion Chapel on the Malham Road industrial Estate recently renovated into a family home. Guided tours of the Old Chapel will be available throughout the day.

properties.name: NOW Gallery and The Gateway Pavilions
properties.description: The NOW Gallery is an art space - contained within two curved glass pavilions linked by a patinated brass-edged canopy - which defines the southern edge of Peninsula Square and acts as a gateway to the south, the cable car and Central Park.

properties.name: St Bonifatius RC German Church
properties.description: Plain modern church serving the German-speaking Catholic community in London. Landmark tower featuring four bells (Whitechapel Bell Foundry), artwork and organ by artists and craftsmen from Germany (Oberammergau, Kevelaer)

properties.name: Koestler Arts Centre – Former Governor's House of HM Prison Wormwood Scrubs
properties.description: The home of the UK's leading prison arts charity, Koestler Arts. Based in the former governor's house of HMP Wormwood Scrubs, paintings, drawings & sculptures from the Koestler Awards, all for sale, cover the walls of the 3-storey building.

properties.name: SPPARC
properties.description: This award-winning practice has an exciting UK & International portfolio & invites you to take part in live debates, explore its workshops, listen to talks & become part of the design process.

properties.name: Goldfinger, Trellick Tower
properties.description: Goldfinger is a social enterprise situated at the foot of the Grade II listed Trellick Tower. We craft bespoke furniture from reclaimed and sustainable materials, with a teaching academy for the local community.

properties.name: Blackhorse Workshop
properties.description: A makerspace offering open access to a fully equipped wood and metal workshop with bench space, tools and machinery. Includes education space, community café and 40 studios for creative businesses.

properties.name: Turning Earth Ceramics E10
properties.description: Ceramics centre for the Lee Valley, covering the entire top floor of an old hardware factory. Three rooms, providing just over 8000 sq ft of floor space; the main room is capped by its original saw-tooth glass roof feature.

properties.name: Kingston Guildhall and History Centre
properties.description: Built in the Georgian style, the Guildhall brought together Kingston's administrative functions. Purpose-built Magistrates Courts were included in the building, part of which are now home to Kingston History Centre.

properties.name: Thamesmead's Lost Landscapes
properties.description: A  walk through Thamesmead's landscapes, including some less well-known hidden spaces. Led by Peabody's Director of Landscape, Dr Phil Askew.

properties.name: The Questors Theatre
properties.description: Originally planned in 1954, the first new theatre after the war, the Questors Playhouse opened in 1964, by which time its design had been followed by the Chichester Festival Theatre and the Crucible, Sheffield.

properties.name: Shrewsbury House
properties.description: Built in 1923, to replace its 18C namesake, Grade ll listed Shrewsbury House is the focus of the Shrewsbury Park Estate conservation area, built 1934-1936 by John Laing and Sons. Two Civil Defence centres are within the grounds.

properties.name: Polish Social and Cultural Association
properties.description: Built 1971-74 in brutalist style. The largest Polish centre in Western Europe, it contains a theatre, the Polish Library, the Polish University Abroad, a Joseph Conrad collection, Jazz Café, art gallery and art collection on public display.

properties.name: Aga Khan Centre
properties.description: The Aga Khan Centre, designed by Pritzker prize winning architect Fumihiko Maki, houses the UK institutions of the Aga Khan Development Network. A unique feature are its six gardens inspired by different regions of the Muslim world.

properties.name: The Old Library, Erith (The Exchange)
properties.description: The first library in Bexley, designed by William Egerton, funded by Andrew Carnegie. Robin Lee Architects have led on more recent repair and renewal works which are due to complete in July 2021. The building is now home to The Exchange.

properties.name: The Nest Community Building and Library, Thamesmead
properties.description: Recently completed library and community space, located at the heart of the regeneration of Thamesmead, on Cygnet Square, just off Harrow Manor Way in South Thamesmead.

properties.name: Low Line - Walking Tour
properties.description: Guided walking tour of the Low Line - an emerging world-class walking destination, linking a network of creative and cultural nodes along the base of the Victorian rail viaducts between Bankside and Bermondsey in south London.

properties.name: London City Island
properties.description: From Canning Town Station our walk begins by crossing the Red Bridge over the River Lea.  Following the river path the walk opens out into the gardens of London City Island.  The walk can then continue into neighbouring Goodluck Hope

properties.name: Monier Road
properties.description:
A new-build development for Peabody in partnership with Hill of 71 homes, with ground floor commercial workspace. 
Each of the 3 blocks has its own identity and palette of materials, arranged around a shared central courtyard.

properties.name: Estorick Collection of Modern Italian Art
properties.description: The Estorick Collection is housed in a beautiful Georgian building previously known as Northampton Lodge. Today, the museum comprises six galleries over three floors, as well as a library, offices, a café and bookshop.

properties.name: King's Cross Masterplan
properties.description: The King’s Cross Masterplan established a framework for the incremental redevelopment of this industrial heritage site through a mix of uses and a network of public spaces structuring new urban blocks and knitting the site into its context.

properties.name: Olympic Legacy Masterplan
properties.description: London’s 2012 Games provided a catalyst for regeneration in the Lower Lea Valley. Guided by the Legacy Masterplan, thousands of new homes and jobs are now being created, stitching together existing communities across the former floodplain.

properties.name: West Kensington and Gibbs Green
properties.description: A led tour around West Kensington & Gibbs Green Estates, who have been at the centre of the political storm of the Earl's Court Regeneration. The decade-long demolition scheme has been defeated but the estates future remains up for debate.

properties.name: Elephant Park
properties.description: Elephant Park is a unique, new two-acre park in Elephant & Castle that boasts Elephant Springs - a spectacular new natural stone and water landscape. Meet the design team and get a guided tour of this new green oasis in the heart of London.

properties.name: St. Mary's Church, Walthamstow Village
properties.description: Churchyard of the ancient Parish Church of St Mary, Walthamstow; an area of three & one third acres containing over 1300 monuments including four Grade II listed tombs. Burial records date from 1743.

properties.name: Torriano Primary School STEM Lab
properties.description: Re-modelling of a 2-storey turret atop an existing Victorian school building to provide a science lab for dynamic hands-on experiments, including a CNC-cut internal timber structure, a shiny shingled rooftop extension and a living façade.

properties.name: Pitched Black
properties.description: Gruff Architects' founder's new home, Pitched Black responds to a challenging site within a conservation area: this black-clad new-build house leans at 10 degrees towards a tree-lined railway cutting, and away from neighbouring gardens.

properties.name: St Margaret's Church, Lee
properties.description:
The Church was built in 1839/41 as a white 'Hall-Church'. 
The 1870s Gothic Revivalism was overseen to a very high standard, by James Brooks and helped by 10 top craftsmen of the day. We also have a WWI Memorial by Violet Pinwill.

properties.name: Cut Glass Studio Ltd, Tottenham Hale
properties.description: Unit used as an art studio in a small industrial estate.

properties.name: Clitterhouse Farm
properties.description: Our Yard at Clitterhouse Farm is a grassroots project working to protect historic Victorian farm outbuildings and transform the entire site into a vibrant and sustainable community hub. Shortlisted for the Open City Stewardship Awards 2021.

properties.name: PEER
properties.description: PEER is a gallery with a 10-metre wide glass façade, bringing art straight onto the street. With its community garden, and Chris Ofili's 'Black Hands' outdoor clock, PEER is also a welcoming and open public space.

properties.name: Latin Village: Pueblito Paisa,  Wards Corner
properties.description: The locally listed, Edwardian corner site and remodelled residential terraces opened as Wards Department Store in 1901, closing in 1972. It was disused until 1985, when a market serving migrant communities opened on the ground floor.

properties.name: Coopers' Hall
properties.description: Coopers' Hall is a late 17th century, timber-framed merchant's house with a Georgian frontage. A Livery Hall since 1957, it features a fine Courtoom, dining room and an impressive staircase spiralling up the entire height of the building.

properties.name: Newfoundland
properties.description:
Newfoundland – Rent an apartment, own the skyline!
Canary Wharf's prestigious and highly anticipated Residential Building. Comprising 636 apartments arranged over 58-storeys, full-height windows wrap around each apartment's living space.

properties.name: Three Rooms Under a New Roof
properties.description: Award winning, beautiful roof extension and conversion of a contemporary timber frame house from an open-plan house to a home that fits perfectly around a family of 4 and an architect's office. Circular Retrofit. Timber construction.

properties.name: Trevithick House
properties.description: Pre war social housing flats, red brick, Georgian sash windows, playground, allotments and washing lines outside.

properties.name: All Hallows Twickenham
properties.description: All Hallows is a Grade I Listed building with an interesting history. Built by Sir Christopher Wren in Lombard Street, London. The tower, bells, cloister and many furnishings were moved to Twickenham in 1939 as the building had subsidence.

properties.name: JTP Studios, Pennington Street Warehouse
properties.description: Pennington Street Warehouse is a Grade II Listed Warehouse, sensitively adapted in 2019 into a vibrant and creative home for architects & masterplanners, JTP.

properties.name: Museum of Neoliberalism
properties.description: The museum is situated in a shopfront in Leegate Shopping Centre, which has been described by the Evening Standard as "the worst shopping precinct in the country."

properties.name: 1 Halliwick Road
properties.description: A low energy refurbishment of an Edwardian house, with rear extension and loft conversion. Wood fibre insulation, MVHR, airtightness layer, triple glazing, timber structure and low embodied energy materials.

properties.name: West Hendon Masterplan
properties.description: The West Hendon masterplan has been developed in order to regenerate a 1960s housing estate adjacent to the Welsh Harp reservoir. It incorporates affordable housing, new public parks, primary school, community centre and commercial space.

properties.name: Alderman Jones House
properties.description: Becontree Estate two storey cottage house with garden located on a banjo.

properties.name: Garden Suburb Community Library
properties.description: The library is located in a shop with flats above. The shop front has not been altered since the 1950s.

properties.name: Fitzroy Park Allotments
properties.description: open allotment site, no buildings

properties.name: Exploring Spring Grove Isleworth
properties.description: Centred on Spring Grove House, once Sir Joseph Banks home the 1850s vision was for John Taylor Jnr designed grand villas.  Today's  wider architecture includes a former college by John Norton & P Massey plus quirky arts & crafts properties.

properties.name: 6 Orsman Road
properties.description: Designed with the whole life carbon footprint of the development in mind, this 5,000 sqm office building explores the principles of reduce, reuse and recycle using low carbon, low impact materials in both its structure and fit out.

properties.name: Reliance Arcade
properties.description: Reliance Arcade is a Grade II Listed covered market in Brixton, London.  The Arcade was constructed in the 1920s and is home to 40 small retail units catering largely to local African-Caribbean communities.

properties.name: Carl Ludwig Franck and the Greening of Finsbury
properties.description: A walk around housing estates designed by Lubetkin and Tecton, Joseph Emberton, and Carl Ludwig Frank 1945-1965, for the Metroplitan Borough of Finsbury, all illustrating the principle of the 'Green City'.

properties.name: Holy Cross Church, Cromer Street
properties.description: Grade ll listed Oxford Movement Anglican church built 1887-88. Historic England describe the exterior as ‘quirky and aggressive’ but the  interior is ‘very spare and elegant, the proportions subtly adjusted’. Elevated choir and sanctuary.

properties.name: StreetGym® Urban Adventure
properties.description: StreetGym® is a one hour, circular urban adventure where we jog from workstation to workstation.  A workstation is an item of street furniture, gradient or architectural feature where we perform bodyweight exercises.

properties.name: Christ Church
properties.description: The church is designed in the Gothic style, with a semicircular barrel-vaulted ceiling, a highly carved chancel screen and magnificent stained glass windows, notably the large West window, depicting Christ the King enthroned in heaven.

properties.name: St Matthias
properties.description: St Matthias' spire is easily visible as you approach Richmond Gate (Richmond Park). It is a Grade 2 listed church built between 1858-1862 with additions in 1884 & 1915. It was remodelled in the 1970s to provide both sacred & social space.

properties.name: Beating the Bounds
properties.description: Setting off from the Festival of Britain site we cover icons of the South Bank before heading into the back streets to see different types of social housing. We travel over to Bankside to see an overview of the historic and contemporary.

properties.name: Slavery and the City
properties.description: We will explore sites and institutions with direct links to the history of slavery and hear why the apologies were made last year, whilst wandering within the story packed streets and alleyways of the Square Mile.

properties.name: Pinter/Wesker Memories Walk
properties.description: Hackney was home to two of Britain’s greatest-ever dramatists – Harold Pinter (1930-2008) and Arnold Wesker (1932-2016). Both working-class, both Jewish, both world-famous. Led by Hackney experts, Laurie Elks and Julia Lafferty.

properties.name: Culture at risk: Crystal Palace Park – a tour with a London Blue Badge Tourist Guide
properties.description:
Explore the world's first dinosaur models hidden in a south London park. The 30 Grade I listed, life-size statues of dinosaurs and other extinct animals at Crystal Palace Park have thrilled
visitors for 166 years. Tour is kids friendly.

properties.name: Wharf Road
properties.description: Designed by architects Pollard Thomas Edwards, the £50m scheme delivered 98 new homes. 80 per cent of the homes are affordable including 64 for social rent. Wharf Road is set around two new communal gardens that face Regents canal.

properties.name: Hoxton Docks
properties.description: Antepavilion Commission offers emerging architects and makers opportunities to create new work through hands-on construction. Works are put on temporary display in Columbia/ Brunswick Wharf, situated on the Regents Canal in Haggerston.

properties.name: Lanterna, Fish Island Village
properties.description: Designed by Lyndon Goode Architects, Lanterna acts as a gateway to our Fish Island Village development with Hill and was shortlisted for a prestigious Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) London Award for architectural excellence.

properties.name: The Naked House
properties.description: The sustainable re-birth of a 3-bedroom Victorian London terrace, completed in 2020. Whittaker Parsons have created a beautiful and functional space; a sanctuary in the middle of the Medway Conservation Area in East London.

properties.name: Flow Gallery
properties.description: The interior of the building was redesigned in 2014 by John Pardey  to combine a craft gallery with a live work space for the gallery owner. Inspired by Kettle's Yard Flow space exhibits ceramics, glass, wood, textiles and jewellery.

properties.name: Rushmore (online only)
properties.description: Rear extension and complete transformation of the Lower Ground Floor of a Victorian House, featuring modern and minimal materials like concrete & plywood.

properties.name: Leverton Street
properties.description: This Victorian terraced house was converted into two self-contained, split level dwellings. Each flat expresses its own identity through the use of colour, materials and bespoke joinery, capturing the personality of each of the clients.

properties.name: National Youth Theatre
properties.description: Completed in Summer 2021, the National Youth Theatre has been redeveloped to double its capacity for studio space and was designed with young people, for young people. Recipient of the Mayor of London's Good Growth Fund.

properties.name: Amott Road
properties.description: Modest single storey side extension, internal kitchen refurbishment and external landscaping works.

properties.name: Bookend House
properties.description: A modest modern timber extension and refurbishment rationalizing internal spaces and adding an external staircase to connect outdoor spaces, located within the Stroud Green Conservation Area.

properties.name: Hedge Lane
properties.description: Remodelling and extension of rear of house to make a kitchen/diner/lounge with ancillary wc and utility spaces.

properties.name: Hyde Park Chapel
properties.description: The four-story Church façade and prominent seven-story tower is covered in Portland stone and highlighted by a golden steeple. The interior features the Christus statue and a large mural of the resurrected Jesus Christ.

properties.name: St Bride's Church, Fleet Street
properties.description: Wren designed building of 1675, interior lost in blitz of 1940, reopened 1957 with 'Wren inspired' interior

properties.name: Core Kensington
properties.description: A Pilates studio like no other. The design combines functionality with creative and beautiful solutions. Influenced by the Norwegian-Mexican background of the owners, full of bespoke elements and details. The result is warm and minimal.

properties.name: Ethelburga Tower, Battersea
properties.description: Ethelburga Tower is a 17-storey block of flats near Battersea Park.  The building was designed by the LCC  Architects Dept with Ove Arup & Partners as consulting engineers.  It was built by Tersons of Finchley and completed in 1966.

properties.name: Hemingford Road
properties.description: A stone extension and complete refurbishment of a Grade II listed Georgian home providing a new dining room and a reflective space which opens to the sky.

properties.name: Boston Manor House and Park Walks
properties.description:
Visitors will be shown around Boston Manor Park on short walks led by volunteers, focusing on the History of Boston Manor House and area.
The House is closed as part of a 5 year redevelopment project, re-opening early 2022.

properties.name: Battersea's Hidden Parks
properties.description: Walking tour introducing nine smaller local parks and public gardens, and revealing their history. Led by Clare Graham, Chair of the Society's Open Spaces Committee and author of 'Discovering Battersea's Open Spaces: a walking guide'.

properties.name: Wood Street Altarpiece
properties.description: Artist and designer Eleanor Hill has designed a public artwork and lighting outside Wood Street Station, Walthamstow, celebrating community gardening. The Artwork is a vitreous enamel trypic, set within a powder-coated aluminium frame.

properties.name: Order and Disorder: Guildhall to Smithfield
properties.description: Head for the dark side of the City and discover tales of crime and punishment, heroes and villains, the great monastic houses, notorious Newgate Prison, body snatchers, Smithfield Market, Bartholomew Fair and the road to the gallows.

properties.name: Ripple Greenway and the Lost Words Art Trail
properties.description:
Ripple Greenway is a beautiful 14-acre linear park and art trail.  Home to Katy Hallett’s steel sculptures, inspired by Robert Macfarlane’s and Jackie Morris’ The Lost Words.
Wooden play and exercise equipment, picnic tables and benches.

properties.name: Ken Artspace
properties.description: Liminal Landscapes; An exhibition of photographs in KENartspace gallery from around Europe. They look primarily thro' windows of varying descriptions revealing the between places of the urban landscape, by architect Ken Taylor.

properties.name: South Norwood Library
properties.description: The purpose-built library is a fine example of brutalist architecture. Built by Hugh Lea, Borough Architect for Croydon, in 1968 the main volume shows miesian influence with an abundance of natural light, interrupted by a concrete cuboid.

properties.name: Build A Birdbox!
properties.description: Encourage new ecosystems to flourish in Canary Wharf by creating your very own birdhouse complete with a teeny tiny paper canary!

properties.name: Escape The Future
properties.description: Join PRP architects in an immersive adventure through a series of games and puzzles. Can you save the world before time runs out? Can you become the superhero that the planet needs?

properties.name: AHMM Mini-City Home Inventors
properties.description: Join AHMM and shrink to the size of a mouse to enter the miniature world of ‘Home Inventors’. Decorate and model a tiny fun place to live and add it to a miniature city – watch it grow and change as homes are added to its streetscape!

properties.name: High-rise LEGO Challenge!
properties.description: Get the whole family involved to build the tallest LEGO structure in the city! Can you construct a tower as high as Canary Wharf and more importantly can you think how your tower would be environmentally friendly?

properties.name: Bridges, Towers and Domes
properties.description: Join NNBJ to experiment with a variety of building materials to create spectacular yet sustainable bridges, towers and domes to add to the impressive skyline of Canary Wharf.

properties.name: Shine On
properties.description: Scribble beautiful colours onto shiny metal surfaces to reflect the architecture and spaces around you to create a memory of Canary Wharf's steel, glass and mirrored buildings.

properties.name: Bugs in the City
properties.description: Design a Bug Hotel inspired by the incredible architecture of the Canary Wharf Estate that will encourage and support biodiversity.

properties.name: Canary Crooners
properties.description: Celebrate the nature of Canary Wharf by chirping like the birds in Jubilee Park and bring the buildings to life through musical storytelling.

properties.name: Bridging AKTion
properties.description: Come and try out AKTII’s replica of Da Vinci’s bridge, conceived by Leonardo Da Vinci in the 16th century. Have a go at making your own mini self- supporting and sustainable version with a colourful lollipop sticks - no glue or tape needed!

properties.name: Canal Crafts
properties.description:
Looking at London’s waterway heritage children will be given examples of traditional canal folk art and encouraged to design their own artwork.
The event will be situated on the east side of the basin on the grass.

properties.name: Enfield To Fork - Pymmes Park
properties.description: The Museum of Enfield is this year bringing its temporary exhibition to you! “From Enfield to Fork” explores the borough’s history and relationship with food, from Roman Enfield to Market Gardening.

properties.name: The Former Peek Frean’s Biscuit Factory, Bermondsey
properties.description: Part of the former Peek Frean’s Biscuit Factory, the birthplace of Twiglets and the Garibaldi, this 1970s warehouse is now at the heart of a new community for Bermondsey.

properties.name: Nunnery Gallery
properties.description: In 1868 the Dominican sisters established a convent in the heart of the East End. Today, the Nunnery Gallery maintains some of its original neo-gothic features, and original hardwood floor and hosts a programme of site-responsive art.

properties.name: 186A Uxbridge Road
properties.description:
Semi-detached residential 2-bed house at the end of a total refurbishment by the owner/architect.
The main works included demolition of str. walls to achieve open plan living, new bathroom, porch, skylight, green roof, UFH and insulation.

properties.name: Friends of Feltham Green
properties.description: Friends of Feltham Green would like to invite you to a walking history tour of Feltham's ponds and places connected to Freddie Mercury who once lived in Feltham.  Plus learn about the amazing Market Garden/Horticultural history.

properties.name: 38 Grosvenor Square
properties.description: A beautiful Mayfair town house c 1727 original to the Square. Transformed 1776 by John Johnson for Duke of Dorset; magnificent staircase, lavish ‘Adamesque’ entertaining suite. Mid-C19 Italianate front by Thomas Cundy.

properties.name: Modern Architecture in Blackheath walk
properties.description: Architect Ana Sutherland will lead a guided tour of the Cator Estate, covering Eric Lyons' Span estates and unique modernist homes designed by architects Patrick Gwynne, Peter Moro and Walter Greaves.

properties.name: New River Head - Quentin Blake Centre for Illustration
properties.description: An intriguing industrial heritage site hiding in plain sight. A fascinating complex of Grade II listed buildings, unseen since the 1950s. Set to be renovated into the Quentin Blake Centre for Illustration by Tim Ronalds Architects.

properties.name: Studio Flox
properties.description: Studio Flox at Watermans Art Centre is a combined arts centre. It is located in Brentford, England alongside the banks of the River Thames overlooking Kew Gardens in West London, England

properties.name: Nourish Hub
properties.description: The Nourish Hub turned a vacant post-office into community space where learning about healthy eating and cooking food is used to connect diverse cultures, teach meaningful skills and bring people together.

properties.name: House for a Cellist
properties.description: Ground floor rear extension, roof terrace and general refurbishment of a Victorian terraced house within a Conservation Area. A reflection on space continuity, compression and expansion. How a square a triangle and a circle interact.

properties.name: Self-guided Old Malden Walk
properties.description: The walk is around Old Malden and covers residential developments within the district. Different styles of suburban architecture includes a selection of modernist housing. There are also historic buildings and other places of interest.

properties.name: The Steamship Project Space
properties.description: With a sculpture garden, performance art in the attic and live music in the bowels of The Steamship, built in the heart of Docklands 1885, the resident artists show how the area has transformed and how they've transformed the former pub.

properties.name: Green House
properties.description: A new exposed CLT-frame house, built on a site once occupied by market garden greenhouses, featuring a planted façade with sliding external screens and a riad-style central atrium, assisting in natural daylighting, ventilation and cooling.

properties.name: Ashraya
properties.description: 'Ashraya' is a contemporary low carbon 'Paragraph 79' house located in the heart of the Chiltern Hills, Hertfordshire. The house was designed by British architects Kirkland Fraser Moor (KFM) and completed in 2021.

properties.name: Mayfair Walk
properties.description: Walk through the heart of Mayfair.  See Churchill’s first apartment, fascinating architecture, London's oldest plane trees, and a Banksy; and walk along (or rather above) the River Tyburn.

properties.name: Monastic London
properties.description: London was once encircled by a ring of powerful religious institutions swept away by the Dissolution, the Great Fire and the Blitz, and yet miraculously some traces remain. This walk will look for evidence of London’s monastic past.

properties.name: Gareth Gardner Gallery
properties.description: Gareth Gardner Gallery is a small gallery space in Deptford, showing photography of architecture and the built environment. The fit-out was designed by architect Studio C102 and its industrial style was inspired by art gallery warehouses.

properties.name: Beacontree Estate: Archive
properties.description: The archive and local studies centre at Valence House is a modern building housing the Borough of Barking and Dagenham's archive. It sits on the same site as Valence House Museum, a medieval moated manor house.

properties.name: DLR Underline Discovery Sessions
properties.description: DLR Underline Discovery Sessions covers a series of events for all ages focused on exploring the spaces under the DLR on the Isle of Dogs, with activities exploring the area's architecture, heritage and the public realm.

properties.name: Vanbrugh Park Estate
properties.description: Vanbrugh Park Estate was designed by Chamberlin, Powell and Bon. The estate shares many stylistic similarities with their wider work such as the semi-circular curved motifs, purposeful use of light, and approach to community living.

properties.name: Wellbeing Walk: South Kensington
properties.description: Our walking tour takes inspiration from the streets of South Kensington to explore practical ways to support wellbeing and find pools of calm in the midst of London's buzz and bustle.

properties.name: C1
properties.description: An open and welcoming building, intent on fostering community. A rooftop basketball court crowns three storeys of studio space, all accessible via open-air staircases doubling as communal spaces.

properties.name: The Church Grove Community Hub
properties.description: A community space built by volunteers in 2019 using reclaimed materials, it is the first element of a mixed-tenure CLT development of 36 units. Shortlisted for the Open City Stewardship Awards 2021

properties.name: C3 - Bureau
properties.description: C3 is home to Bureau, a members club at the heart of Design District. Its undulating white facade creates informal pockets of space on the interior, ideal for flexible working models.

A three-storey decorative folly, drawing sightlines through the central park towards the Victorian terraces beyond. The structure is timber studwork, with the design featuring a galvanized steel, powder coated staircase in vibrant yellow.

properties.name: Ashbourne Grove
properties.description: Single storey rear and side extension and full internal refurbishment of a ground floor flat.

properties.name: Town of tomorrow: Thamesmead Through Film
properties.description: Touted as a ‘town of tomorrow’, Thamesmead’s ambitious masterplan captured global attention when it was first built in the 1960s. This new town offered a leap forward into what was seen as futuristic living for visitors and residents.

properties.name: Spitalfields to Stepney Green: 500 years of immigration
properties.description: Explaining the arrival and large-scale departure of the Huguenot and Jewish communities from the area through the buildings and streets. Charting the arrival of the Bangladeshi community and how the area and its population is changing again

properties.name: London Living Streets and Footways London
properties.description: A walk from St Pancras station to highlight the amazing new traffic-free piazza being created in the Strand. The walk will follow a Footways route https://footways.london/ along attractive,low pollution streets, and end at St Mary le Strand

properties.name: East India Dock Basin Explorer
properties.description: The walk will take in East India Dock Basin, Bow Creek and Trinity Buoy Wharf looking at the history of the area. Wildlife is also a key subject on East India Dock Basin and birdwatchers can bring binoculars.

properties.name: Eco Show Home
properties.description: Waltham Forest Council has transformed a Victorian terrace into an Eco Home to showcase best practice retrofitting to be more carbon friendly. Features home improvements that reduce carbon footprint and help tackle the climate emergency.

properties.name: Marylebone Village: Home to The Howard de Walden Estate
properties.description: This fun and engaging walking tour led by expert guide Mike Althorpe - an urban historian, architectural researcher, educator and story teller - will explore the architecture and history of this urban village.

properties.name: The Mysterious Black Tudors - Family Trail
properties.description: Celebrate Open House Festival 2021 with this fun and interactive family event about Britain's forgotten history of the Black Tudors.

properties.name: Becontree Estate Walking Tours with Bill Jennings
properties.description: Tours with Bill Jennings, former Becontree Estate Housing Manager. Tours will highlight the heritage and history of the estate, including Valence House museum and library, Kingsley Hall and the unique architectural features of the estate
